That will absolutely be doable.  Just working out the precise mechanics.

There will also be mechanics for extending hab time without having to just add more space or hab multipliers.  The angle I am working on currently makes the assumption that supplies are your bare essentials.  Sure, you can survive with a sponge bath and scraping algae off of the walls... but if you make things a bit more comfy (similar to how the U.S. Navy ensures submariners have some of the best food out there, and some private companies take similar measures for remote employees), you're going to be a bit more tolerant of the living conditions.

This has also been discussed in relation to space travel, with the idea of supporting limited amounts of things like fish, etc. - that despite being not as space efficient as scraping off algae, can have a dramatic impact on morale for a crew on a long journey.

> Help! How do I rescue an kerbalnaut who's run out of life support? Valentina is in orbit around Minmus and has run out of NOMS. Her capsule doesn't have a docking port and she is too grumpy to EVA.
> 

You have a couple of options:

If all she needs are supplies, you could use <abbr title="Kerbal Attachment System (mod)">KAS</abbr> and an engineer to bolt a supply pack to the side of her craft. If I recall correctly, the <abbr title="Umbra Space Industries (a collection of mods)">USI</abbr> Survival Pack mod has a really handy tiny supply bag with ~25 supplies or so...? Note that if Val also needs habitation time that this will not solve that problem.

Alternatively, you can use the Klaw to dock a new vessel to Val's, even though hers doesn't have a docking port. As soon as they dock, Val should be able to access any supplies and habitation time-boosting parts (just about anything that provides crew capacity counts). If she's just stranded in <abbr title="Low Kerbin Orbit">LKO</abbr>, you could even try just docking a tiny probe with a klaw and using it to de-orbit Val's craft (since the probe would then be in command of Val's vessel, and probes do not need supplies or habitation time).

Good luck with your rescue!

I haven't personally tried this, but DMagic has a page of smaller mods ([<font color="#000080">Found Here</font>](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/108704-11x-dmagics-modlets-latest-modlet-flexible-docking-wip-release-v03-6-30-2016/&page=1)) including EVA Resource Transfer, which claims to allow you to connect a resource transfer pipe to two vessels. This allows you to transfer resources, but unlike using a <abbr title="Kerbal Attachment System (mod)">KAS</abbr> pipe it doesn't actually connect the two vessels together. It's not the same as carrying supplies on a kerbal's back, but it may work.

As an aside (because the thread is huge), what had you settle on 16.2 Supplies per kerbal per day? I've been half tempted to refactor the supplies ratio (while keeping the ultimate capacities, weights, and costs in line with base balancing) so it's 1 supply per day per kerbal just to let the 'mental math' be easier - a radially mounted Supplies box is then ~6 kerbal-days worth, and you know this just by looking at it... ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif ":)")

It's about half of the 32kg a human uses - 90% of that is water (including hygeine, etc.) with zero recycling.  Baseline tech is Gemini style, no recyclers are assumed until you add them in.  Yes, Kerbal time is also scaled back, but so are distances, etc.
Great mod. Just wondering what is the volume in liters of 1 unit of NOMS and of 1 unit of mulch?

[@Rafael acevedo](%7B___base_url___%7D/index.php?/profile/84946-rafael-acevedo/) When you think about it only the mass of the supplies is relevant for rocket calculations. The volume of NOMS will depend on the types of snacks provided (think chocolate bar vs packet of crisps), and as for mulch... google says "*1.0 g/cm3 is accepted as the average density of human feces. Therefore, 27 L of feces weighs around 27 Kg. If you're dealing with sinkers or floaters, it'll change.*"

edit: after some additional searching (pretty sure the government is watching me now!) I found [this document](http://history.nasa.gov/SP-368/s6ch2.htm) which contains actual numbers for real life space mulch! hehe my favourite line is "*The bag was kneaded to rupture the inner pouch and mix the germicide with the wastes*"t (so the next time Jebediah complains about tedious data collection, remind him how lucky he is!! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif ":D") )
